information.title: Definition
information.description: Judicial review is the power of the judiciary to examine the constitutionality of legislative enactments and executive orders of both the Central and State governments.

information.title: Constitutional Basis
information.description: While not explicitly mentioned, judicial review is derived from various provisions of the Constitution, particularly Articles 13, 32, 136, 141, 142, 226, and 227.

information.title: Article 13
information.description: It declares that all laws that are inconsistent with or in derogation of the fundamental rights shall be void.

information.title: Article 32 and 226
information.description: These articles empower the Supreme Court and High Courts respectively to issue writs for the enforcement of fundamental rights.

information.title: Scope
information.description: Judicial review in India extends to legislative, executive, and administrative actions. It can declare laws, ordinances, orders, bye-laws, regulations, customs, or usages unconstitutional.

information.title: Limitations
information.description: The judiciary cannot question the wisdom of the legislature in enacting a law. It can only determine if the law is constitutional or not.

information.title: Basic Structure Doctrine
information.description: Established in the Kesavananda Bharati case (1973), this doctrine states that the basic features of the Constitution cannot be altered or destroyed through amendments by the Parliament.

information.title: Judicial Activism
information.description: Through judicial review, the Indian judiciary has often been proactive in protecting rights and ensuring good governance, leading to what is sometimes called 'judicial activism'.

quizQuestions.question: Which Article of the Constitution declares that laws inconsistent with fundamental rights shall be void?
Which case established the Basic Structure Doctrine?
Which of the following is NOT a basis for judicial review in the Indian Constitution?
What does the Basic Structure Doctrine state?
options: The basic features of the Constitution cannot be altered or destroyed through amendments
The Constitution can be amended in any way by the Parliament
Only the Supreme Court can amend the Constitution
The Constitution cannot be amended at all
quizQuestions.correctAnswer: The basic features of the Constitution cannot be altered or destroyed through amendments

quizQuestions.question: Which courts in India have the power of judicial review?
options: Both Supreme Court and High Courts
quizQuestions.correctAnswer: Both Supreme Court and High Courts
